prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Maser lines can have widths as narrow as 1.0 km/s, but they are often clustered in blended groups and so we are likely to get our best spectrum after spectral averaging to ~2 km/s channels. We have thus specified a channel width of ~1.7 km/s.

The masers are expected to be point sources even at sub-milliarcsecond resolution, so we have no restrictions on configuration or desired angular resolution. We are only concerned with spectra for these observations.

This is an exploratory project, so our knowledge of what to expect for the intensities of the SiO maser lines is limited. In the Wang et al. (2014) observations, the SiO masers peaked at ~20 mJy, so we use this as a guide. We thus set our RMS to 4 mJy per linewidth (i.e., per ~1.7 km/s channel), so that a 20 mJy line will be detected at ~5 sigma.

Maximizing velocity coverage is critical to our science, since our aim is to detect gas closer to the black hole (and therefore orbiting at a higher velocity, i.e. >1000 km/s) than the 22 GHz water lines. Our specified channel width is chosen to be able to detect the narrow, isolated maser lines (with typical linewidths of <~2 km/s) often associated with maser flaring. These simultaneous requirements drive the high data rate.
If this data rate is prohibitive, we would be willing to apply spectral averaging to reduce the data size. The primary science goals would still be achievable with 2-channel averaging.

ALMA is by far the most efficient telescope for making this observation. Although NGC 4258 sits at a high declination, it remains above 15 degrees elevation for ~4 hours per day. In this proposal we are not aiming for imaging, only a spectrum, so the loss of UV coverage that arises from observing a low-elevation source is not an issue. Though the masers will be point sources at even the highest resolution that ALMA can achieve, the low elevation of the target means that we'd ideally like to observe with at least a modestly extended configuration, to minimize antenna shadowing.

The masers are expected to be point sources even at sub-milliarcsecond resolution, so we have no restrictions on configuration or desired angular resolution. We are only concerned with spectra for these observations.

Our specified channel width is chosen to be able to detect the narrow, isolated maser lines (with typical linewidths of <~2 km/s) often associated with maser flaring. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to search for 86 GHz SiO megamasers in 12 galaxies known to have 22 GHz H2O megamaser emission, arising from gas in the circumnuclear accretion disk around the central supermassive black hole. We are motivated in part by the recent detection of SiO as a megamaser in the circumnuclear disk of NGC 1068 (Wang et al. 2014), which is known to host a strong 22 GHz water megamaser. If we detect a disk-like profile in SiO emission, we can use the known (from 22 GHz observations) dynamics to associate the SiO masers with specific regions of the circumnuclear disk. Furthermore, a detection of SiO megamasers in a disk system would provide a fantastic target for current millimeter-wave VLBI facilities, opening up opportunities to map the innermost regions (<~0.1 pc) of the circumnuclear disk.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Virginia, University of

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
